content.description:
More good crimping, starting on cool black dike features. Climbs between Mickey Mantle and The Fiend the whole way, via TR on MM anchors.

Start a few feet left of MM or directly under big black dike (crimp pull up to start).

climbs.name: Ultimatum
climbs.fa: John Long and Gib Lewis, April 1972

content.description: This face route has a serious runout above the first bolt.  To descend, rappel 90 feet from an anchor at the left end of the ledge.  It is in the sun all day.
content.protection: 3 bolts, one or two longs slings, and some gear for the belay

climbs.name: Toxic Waltz
climbs.fa: Geoff Archer, Kay Buskirk, and Terry McCarthy, July 1989

content.description: Small holds edging/friction leads past 4 bolts.  The climbing isn't all that bad, it's just a little on the short side.  It would be more memorable if it were longer.
content.location: Extreme right side of the Right Smooth Sole.  Directly above the tunnel under and boulder move on the way to the Smooth Sole from the Sunshine Face.

climbs.name: Tango
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines and Frank Bentwood, June 2010

content.description:
This climb is on the far right side of the Smooth Sole Wall, on a small buttress located just above where the approach trail tunnels under a large boulder.

Tango is a 5 bolt slab just left of

Toxic Waltz

. The crux is getting to the second bolt.

This climb is quite memorable.  The crux first pitch starts easy, but then moves up onto a steep arete.  Exposed stemming and side pulls take you up to a belay ledge.  An easy second pitch leads to the top, and you can walk off.
content.protection: small to medium gear, plus one bolt

content.description: At the top of the pitch, instead of moving right to finish on Sensuous Corner, move a bit left and climb staright up the arete to the top.

A flake (5.8) near the bottom is a bit loose, but the rock on the rest of this face climb is excellent.  The climbing up the initial flake is poorly protected.  The crux move is right by a bolt.  Higher up is a very runout 5.9 move, where a fall would be serious.  The ledge at the top has a bolted anchor at its left end, allowing a 90 foot rappel back to the ground.  This climb is in the sun all day.
content.protection: 2 bolts, a fixed pin, and gear to 3" for the belay

climbs.name: Mickey Mantle
climbs.fa: Jim Wilson and Phil Warrender, April 1972

content.description: This is perhaps the best route on the Smooth Soul Wall.  It has mantles, edges, friction, and a novel traverse, all on excellent rock.  With only three bolts and fairly sustained climbing, there are substantial runouts.  Rappel 90 feet from a ledge at the end of the route (or continue up with an easy second pitch and walk off).  It is in the sun all day.

Not really a new route so much as a link-up of two existing classics (

Mickey Mantle

and

The Fiend

), but it's also the easiest face route to the top of the wall. It wouldn't surprise me if this has been done before, but I've never seen or heard of it anywhere.

Climb

Mickey Mantle

to the 2nd bolt, move left to join

The Fiend

at it's 3rd bolt, and then follow that route to the top. A harder and better protected variation can be done by heading left a little more after the 3rd bolt and clipping one more bolt for the 5.9 finish of The Fiend.

climbs.name: Howard's Fifty Footer
climbs.fa: Paul Morrell and Scott Erler, June 1992

content.description: Despite the name, I found the protection to be reasonably good on this thin face route.  To descend, rappel 90 feet from a ledge.  It is in the sun all day.

climbs.name: Glass Menagerie
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines and Patty Kline, June 2003

content.description: Begin at the very bottom right-hand side of the main cliff. Climb the smooth slab just right of Pink Royd, ending on the right shoulder about half way up the face.
content.protection: A few flakes provide sparse pro, to 3 inches.

climbs.name: The Fiend
climbs.fa: Jim Wilson and Phil Warrender, June 1972

content.description: The Fiend is a quality thin face route.  When the rock exfoliated, it left a few long, 1/2 inch wide edges that you can use for traverses.  A 20 foot runout up to the first bolt is quite scary - the runouts above are milder.  Rappel 90 feet from a two bolt anchor on a ledge at the top.  This climb is in the sun all day.

climbs.name: Disco Duck
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines and Patty Kline, June 2004.

content.description:
Start in a little left-facing corner about 15 feet right of Toxic Waltz. Follow the crack system until it peters out, then easy face climbing leads to the top of the small buttress.The crux is the starting corner.

Descend down the gully behind the formation.
content.protection: To 3 inches, including a thin nut (#5 Microstopper) for the start.

content.description: This deep, prominent chimney divides the Smooth Soul Wall into two roughly equal parts.  A short, awkward crack (crux) leads to a long, wide, fun, easy chimney.  The crux is well protected.  Walk off from the top.
content.protection: standard rack, including some larger pieces

climbs.name: Battle of the Bulge
climbs.fa: Matt Cox, Randy Vogel & Steve Emerson, 1976

content.description: This is a terrific thin face climb, with three crux sections.  The moves are quite varied.  The start (15 or 20 feet up to the first bolt) is shared with The Fiend, and has the only scary runout of the route.  This climb is in the sun all day.
content.protection: 8 bolts to a double bolt anchor - 150' rappel to the ground
